javax.time.calendrical

Interface DateTimeAccessor.Query<R>

  • Enclosing interface:
    DateTimeAccessor

    public static interface DateTimeAccessor.Query<R>
    Strategy for querying a date-time object.

    This interface allows different kinds of query to be modeled. Examples might be a query that checks if the date is the day before February 29th in a leap year, or calculates the number of days to your next birthday.

    Implementations should not normally be used directly. Instead, the DateTimeAccessor.query(Query) method must be used: 

       dateTime = dateTime.query(query);

    See DateTimeAdjusters for a standard set of adjusters, including finding the last day of the month.

    Implementation notes

    This interface must be implemented with care to ensure other classes operate correctly. All implementations that can be instantiated must be final, immutable and thread-safe.

    • Field Detail

      • ZONE_ID

        static final DateTimeAccessor.Query<ZoneId> ZONE_ID
        The special constant for the query for ZoneId.

        If the target DateTimeAccessor has a zone ID, then querying it with this constant must return the chronology.

      • CHRONO

        static final DateTimeAccessor.Query<Chrono<?>> CHRONO
        The special constant for the query for Chrono.

        If the target DateTimeAccessor has a chronology, then querying it with this constant must return the chronology.

      • TIME_PRECISION

        static final DateTimeAccessor.Query<ChronoUnit> TIME_PRECISION
        The special constant for the query for the minimum supported time unit.

        If the target DateTimeAccessor represents a consistent or complete date-time, date or time then this must return the smallest precision actually supported. Note that fields such as NANO_OF_DAY and NANO_OF_SECOND are defined to always return ignoring the precision, thus this is the only way to find the accurate minimum supported unit.

        For example, GregorianCalendar has a precision of MILLIS, whereas LocalDate and ZoneOffset have no time precision and thus returns null.

    • Method Detail

      • doQuery

        R doQuery(DateTimeAccessor dateTime)
        Implementation of the strategy to query the specified date-time object.

        This method is not intended to be called by application code directly. Instead, the DateTimeAccessor.query(Query) method must be used: 

           dateTime = dateTime.query(query);

        Implementation notes

        The implementation queries the input date-time object to return the result. For example, an implementation might query the date and time, returning the astronomical Julian day as a BigDecimal.

        This interface can be used by calendar systems other than ISO. Implementations may choose to document compatibility with other calendar systems, or validate for it by querying the chronology from the input object.

        Parameters:
        dateTime - the date-time object to query, not null
        Returns:
        the queried value, avoid returning null
        Throws:
        DateTimeException - if unable to query
        ArithmeticException - if numeric overflow occurs
